metadata.case_name: Assessee v. Commissioner of Income-tax, Madras

facts.text: Appellant is a resident and ordinarily resident in India and carried on extensive trade in Colombo in grains, fodder, gram and other food-stuffs for cattle and poultry.
For assessment year 1943-1944, appellant showed turnover of Rs. 17,74,825 and gross profit of Rs. 63,217 (about 3.5%). For two previous years, gross profits were 9% and 8% respectively.
Income-tax Officer by order dated March 20, 1948 rejected accounts, estimated turnover at Rs. 20,00,000 and gross income at Rs. 3,00,000 (15% profit).
Appellate Assistant Commissioner confirmed ITO's order.

Income-tax Appellate Tribunal by order dated September 14, 1951 rejected account books but accepted turnover, computed profits at 15% on grains imported from India and 12.5% on grains purchased in Ceylon. Held correct profit could not be deduced from books.

Tribunal reasons for rejection: (1) no vouchers for several purchases in Colombo, especially over Rs. 3,00,000; (2) no quantitative tally for grains and materials; (3) big sum for purchase of export licenses from India and Rs.19,000 purchases in Tuticorin with small cash shown; (4) outsiders' cheques entered without proof; (5) big sum invested in India property without money from Colombo.
Excess Profits Tax for chargeable period Feb 10, 1942 to Jan 16, 1943 based on 1943-44 Income-tax assessment.
Appellant applied to Tribunal on Nov 21, 1951 under s.66(1) for case stated on four questions; Tribunal refused on Feb 12, 1950 stating no question of law.
High Court of Madras dismissed application under s.66(2) on Feb 26, 1953.
Special leave granted by Supreme Court; petition amended to appeal against Tribunal and High Court orders.
For 1944-45, turnover Rs.10,35,748, gross profit 10.7%; Tribunal estimated 12.5%.
For 1946-47, turnover Rs.5,98,728, gross profit 8.7%; Tribunal estimated 10%.
For EPTA Nos. 300,301,302 of 1952-53, chargeable periods Jan 1943-Feb 1944 and Feb 1945-Feb 1946.
Tribunal for other years applied s.13 after rejecting books; appellant applied under s.66(1) on two points, dismissed Jan 15, 1954; no s.66(2) to HC, direct special leave.
ITO considered: export prohibition except license, shortage in Ceylon, dubious means, no price control part year, manufacturing higher profits; other cases up to 20%; bombing in Colombo.
No stock register or manufacturing account produced.

legal_issues.text: Whether the Income-tax Appellate Tribunal was justified in applying the proviso to s.13 of the Income-tax Act.
Whether the reasons set out by the Tribunal are sufficient to invoke s.13 proviso.
Whether Tribunal had jurisdiction to apply s.13 and estimate after disagreeing with department.
Whether Tribunal justified in assessing under s.13 without adequate opportunity to assessee.
Whether Department right under proviso to s.13 absent finding that profits cannot be deduced from books or no regular method employed.
Whether sufficient materials for profit rates of 12.5% and 10%.

petitioner_arguments.text: Tribunal not justified in applying proviso to s.13; power arises only if no regular method employed and profits cannot be properly deduced.
Percentage unjustified, relied on material (profits in other cases) without opportunity to meet, violates natural justice per Dhakeshwari Cotton Mills.
petitioner_arguments.legal_basis: Dhakeshwari Cotton Mills Ltd. v. CIT (1955) 1 SCR 941

petitioner_arguments.text: Non-production of stock register not sufficient defect to apply proviso.

respondent_arguments.text: Books defective: no vouchers, no quantitative tally, unexplained payments/cheques/investments; correct profits not deducible; proviso applies.
Profit estimates reasonable considering market conditions, shortage, manufacturing.

court_reasoning.text: Proviso to s.13 applies where regular method employed but profits cannot properly be deduced; Tribunal gave sufficient reasons including no vouchers, no quantitative tally, no stock register etc.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Various defects justify rejection of books and application of proviso.

court_reasoning.text: No violation of natural justice; reference to other cases' profits not basis for conclusion or percentage, merely ancillary support; already in ITO order, no objection raised earlier.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Dhakeshwari distinguished as no undisclosed information supplied to Tribunal.

court_reasoning.text: Absence of stock register serious defect in such business needing quantitative tally; Pandit Brothers distinguished as accounts there accepted.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Stock register important per Ghanshyam Das; proviso attracted.

court_reasoning.text: ITO/Tribunal not bound by book profits even if method accepted; estimates reasonable.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Per Bombay Cycle and Mac Millan.

court_reasoning.text: No error in relying on prior Tribunal decisions for same assessee.

holdings.text: Tribunal justified in applying proviso to s.13 as correct profits could not be deduced from defective books.
No violation of natural justice; profit estimates proper.
Absence of stock register and other defects sufficient for proviso.

precedents_cited.case_name: Dhakeshwari Cotton Mills Ltd. v. Commissioner of Income-tax, West Bengal
precedents_cited.relevance: No undisclosed information used by Tribunal without opportunity.

precedents_cited.case_name: Pandit Brothers v. Commissioner of Income-tax, Delhi
precedents_cited.relevance: Different facts; stock register absence not serious where accounts accepted.

precedents_cited.case_name: Ghanshyam Das Permanand v. Commissioner of Income-tax, C.P. Berar
precedents_cited.relevance: Importance of stock register for verifying accounts by quantitative tally.

precedents_cited.case_name: Bombay Cycle Stores Company Ltd. v. Commissioner of Income-tax
precedents_cited.relevance: Proviso applies if correct profits not deducible despite materials.

precedents_cited.case_name: Commissioner of Income-tax v. Mac Millan Co.
precedents_cited.relevance: ITO not bound by book profits even if method accepted.

statutes_cited.name: Income-tax Act
statutes_cited.relevance: Proviso allows estimation if profits not properly deducible from regular accounts; applications for reference refused.

outcome.summary: All six appeals dismissed as Tribunal justified in rejecting books and applying proviso to s.13 for profit estimation; no error or natural justice violation.

key_quotes.text: "In view of these defects, we are clearly of opinion that the correct profit could not be deduced from the books produced by the assessee, and accordingly hold that proviso to Section 13 of the Act applies in this case."
key_quotes.speaker: court

key_quotes.text: "the method adopted by the assessee must prima facie prevail where it is regularly employed, though the Income-tax Officer can resort to the proviso if the method is such that true profits cannot be correctly determined therefrom."
key_quotes.speaker: court

key_quotes.text: "No such case arises in the present appeal. No information, as in Dhakeshwari's Case was supplied to the Tribunal by any one and taken into consideration by it."
key_quotes.speaker: court
